module.title: uiread
module.p:
uiread is an non-declinable masculine generic quantity noun with two main senses –
resultative so much/many that, such a lot that, e.g. Tha uiread chon aig Màiri is gu bheil i daonnan sgìth Mary has so many dogs that she’s always tired.
equative comparative as much/many as, e.g. Tha uiread chon aig Màiri is a tha cait aig Dòmhnall. Mary has as many dogs as Donald has cats.
In terms of the stuff being quantified (i.e. the standard of comparison), uiread generally works like other generic quantity nouns –

ul.li:
When the standard of comparison is new information, it is usually expressed as a noun modifier/specifier of the quantity noun, either the genitive singular of a mass noun or the genitive plural of a count noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid uiread fìona ... Rachel drank so/as much wine ...
Tha uiread chon aig Màiri ... Mary has so/as many dogs ...
Bha uiread fiodha ’s a dhèanadh aon sgeilp.
There was as much wood as would make one shelf. [enough to??] td. 616
Chan eil uiread iarraidh air a-nis.
There isn’t as much demand for it now.td. 616

When the standard of comparison is already known, it is usually introduced by the partitive preposition de of governing a specified (i.e. ‘definite’) noun –
Dh’òl Raonaid uiread den fhìona ... Rachel drank so/as much of the wine ...
Cheannaich Màiri uiread de mo choin ... Mary bought so/as many of my dogs ...

When the standard of comparison is already known, and has just been referred to, or can be inferred, uiread can occur on its own –
Dh’òl Raonaid uiread ... Rachel drank so/as much ...
Tha uiread aig Màiri ... Mary has so/as many ...
Tha uiread agam ’s a th’ agadsa.
I have as much as you have. td. 994
Thoir dhomh uiread ’s a tha aig Iain.
Give me as much as John has. td. 396

Alternatively, uiread can be followed by one of the de prepositional pronouns –
Dh’òl Raonaid uiread dheth ... Rachel drank so/as much of it ...
Tha uiread dhiubh aig Màiri ... Mary has so/as many of them ...
Cha do rinn e uiread dheth ’s a dh’fhaodadh e.
He didn’t make as much of it as he might [have done].td. 615

uiread mu (dheidhinn) so/as much [information/knowledge] about some topic –
Dh’ionnsaich Màiri uiread mu choin ... Mary learned so much about dogs.
td. 60

uiread ri (dhèanamh) so/as much to do –
Tha uiread ri dhèanamh aig Raonaid ... Rachel has so/as much to do ...
Bha uiread ri a dhèanamh is gun do chuir e eagal orm.
There was so much to do that it scared me.td. 615

module.p:
However, there is some variation in usage to be found here.
Chaill mi uiread de thìde.
I lost such a lot of time. td. 397
The e iongantach gun do rinn e uiread de obair ionmholta anns an ùine sin.
It is amazing that he performed so much praiseworthy work in that time. td. 616
... a bha a’ cur uiread de dhragh air ...
... which was giving him so much bother ... td. 616
In its resultative sense, uiread ... is gun/nach ... describes a situation which is a result of some other situation involving a significantly large quantity of something –

ul.li:
Dh’òl Raonaid uiread fìona is gun do chuir i a-mach. Rachel drank so much wine that she was sick.
Bha uiread ri a dhèanamh is gun do chuir e eagal orm.
There was so much to do that it scared me.Mark (2004) td. 615
Tha uiread chon aig Màiri is nach eil airgead sam bith aice. Mary has so many dogs that she has no money at all.

module.p: When there is no explicit result clause, this construction often has exclamatory force –

ul.li: Tha uiread chon aig Màiri! Mary has so many dogs!

li.tr: I lost such a lot of time.

li.gd: The e iongantach gun do rinn e uiread de obair ionmholta anns an ùine sin.
li.tr: It is amazing that he performed so much praiseworthy work in that time.

li.gd: ... a bha a’ cur uiread de dhragh air ...
li.tr: ... which was giving him so much bother ...

module.p:
In its equative sense, uiread ... is a ... describes a situation involving two different quantities of the same size –
Tha uiread chon aig Màiri is a tha cait aig Dòmhnall. Mary has as many dogs as Donald has cats.
Dh’òl Raonaid uiread fìona is a dh’òl Seumas. Rachel drank as much wine as James [did].
Tha uiread agam ’s a th’ agadsa.
I have as much as you have. Dwelly td. 994
Bha uiread fiodha ’s a dhèanadh aon sgeilp.
There was as much wood as would make one shelf. [enough to??] Mark (2004) td. 616
Thoir dhomh uiread ’s a tha aig Iain.
Give me as much as John has. Watson (2001) td. 396
Where there is no explicit target of comparison, this can be supplied from context –

ul.li: Tha trì cait aig Dòmhnall. Tha uiread chon aig Màiri. Donald has three cats. Mary has as many dogs.

module.p: When equative uiread is used within the scope of a negative particle, it is usually interpreted as a negative comparative less/fewer than, rather than as a simple negative equative not equal to –

ul.li: Chan eil uiread chon aig Màiri ’s a tha cait aig Dòmhnall. Mary doesn’t have as many dogs as Donald has cats. [She has fewer.]
Cha do dh’òl Raonaid uiread fìona ’s a dh’òl Seumas. Rachel didn’t drink as much wine as James [did]. [She drank less.]

li.tr: I have not as much as that

li.gd: Cha do rinn e uiread dheth ’s a dh’fhaodadh e.
li.tr: He didn’t make as much of it as he might [have done].

li.gd: Chan eil uiread iarraidh air a-nis.
li.tr: There isn’t as much demand for it now.

ul.li:
na h-uiread a modicum of, a great quantity of
Bha na h-uiread de thèarainteachd againn.
We had a certain amount / modicum of security. td. 396
Chaill mi na h-uiread de thìde.
I lost so much time / such a lot of time. td. 397

leth uiread half as much as
Tha iad a’ dèanamh a leth uiread de mhearachan a-nise.
The are making half as many mistakes now.td. 616
uiread eile as much again, twice as much as(?)

cha/nach/gun uiread agus + numeral not so much as, not even as much as
gun uiread agus leth-cheud sgillinn
without even 50p / without so much as 50ptd. 396

multiplication
a dhà uiread a dhà
two times two, twice twotd. 397
